outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: I finally landed a job as a data scientist

all_paragraphs: Update: Hey! Thanks for taking the time to read this article — but before you do, I made a video that talks about the same topic and can be found here which you might find useful.

I’m sure those that have asked the same question are already aware of the current situation in the job market. Companies are generating and collecting more data than ever. They need people that are equipped with the necessary skills to derive actionable insights from data to generate more profit.

This trend has spurred a series of new master’s programs from universities everywhere to satisfy this demand. A lot of prospective students are asking the same questions that I were asking a few years ago:
Do I need a master’s to be a Data Scientist? Is it worth the time and money?

I’ve received a number of messages from prospective students asking similar questions. My short, biased answer would be that yes, it’s worth the time and money. It also most definitely helped me with my career. In reality though, it really depends on the individual.
I graduated with a maths degree in 2016 without any knowledge of data science. So like most graduates, I applied for analyst jobs through a graduate recruitment agency.
Once I was working as an analyst, I realised there’s a lot of things a maths degree doesn’t teach you, both technically and socially.
At the start, I strugged with basic things like querying a SQL database. It was hard creating simple data visualisations and then communicating the results to stakeholders.

As I became more comfortable being an analyst, I began learning about data science and machine learning. It was during that time that I realised I lacked the technical skill and experience about programming in general. This was especially true for Python which is arguably the most popular data science language at the moment.
I wanted to learn more about the computer science aspect of data science, but it was really hard for me to stay disciplined whilst working a full-time job. I decided that I had three options:

The last two options felt unrealistic for me. I lacked both the experience and technical skill, and finding the discipline to stay on track with self-studying was hard. Plus, there’s no guarantee the company could offer such a position in the future.

Working as an analyst probably could’ve still provided me the relevant experience required. I could also develop my technical skills by doing projects on the side. The problem with this approach was the lack of rigour and structure. It was what I needed to achieve anything significant in a short amount of time.

Hence, it made the most sense for me to create some savings and go with the first choice. Devote a year of my time to study something that I was passionate about. I decided that I’d rather quit than work as an analyst for a few years with only the hopes of transitioning to a Data Scientist role later.

I graduated from my master’s a few months before the lockdown happened in the UK. During those first few months, I was having little success with my job search and the lockdown made the situation worse.

I decided to take a step back and re-evaluate the skills and projects that I had to offer which would make me stand out. Despite lacking in work experience, the data science master’s was always a good starting point for my CV.

I felt much more qualified after having the master’s despite my little work experience. Passing the initial job requirements was noticeably easier due to the things I’ve learnt from it. It gave me plenty of projects to talk about and provided a much stronger foundation to work on my own projects. Tackling those projects would’ve been siginificantly harder before I started the master’s.

For example, I worked on a computer vision project during lockdown to improve my data processing and machine learning knowledge. At the time, it would’ve been hard to muster the confidence to start and finish the project.
And I think it’s that confidence which had the biggest impact to me. The structure of a master’s really forced me to learn a lot in a very short amount of time.
I could progress much quicker to being a data scientist by building the foundation that I was lacking previously.

In August, I finally landed a job as a data scientist. It would’ve been difficult for me to get this position without the experience and qualification gained from the master’s degree. My job search was easier during the summer thanks to the portfolio that I built, an improved data science skillset and the understanding of what companies are looking for in a data scientist.

With all that being said, I still don’t think someone needs a data science master’s. The best part about the internet is that almost everything is available online. You can build a portfolio of the same quality if you have the motivation and discipline to study and finish meaningful projects on your own. You’ll save a lot of money too.

Additionally, if you’re already working, then returning to school isn’t easy. Going from financial stability to having no income can be a difficult transition. If you already work in a data-oriented role with a senior position, the experience alone is likely more valuable. You can do projects outside of work to make up for the technical skills that you think you’re lacking.

But it does have the potential to fast-track your career to working as a data scientist. If you’re in a situation like I was, I still think it’s one of the best ways to get a solid understanding of what data science is about. You won’t regret starting the degree if you’re willing to sacrifice the time and money and you’re truly passionate about data science.

An important thing to keep in mind though, is that not all data science masters are created equal. Master’s degrees aren’t cheap these days so it’s important to do your research into what each course offers. You can then decide whether the selection of modules (and especially projects) will actually be of any use to you in the future.

Those that have a fair amount of work experience with data will probably do better at this. However, I’ve seen many students avoiding harder modules and then regret it later. In some cases, they might end up needing to learn it again at work (e.g. machine learning).
Be smart about the time spent during the year, and I’m sure the investment will be worth it.
